contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Bligh Reef NOAA 16708.png|thumb|alt=Map excerpt showing Bligh Reef.|Map excerpt showing Bligh Reef and automated beacon.]] '''Bligh Reef''', sometimes known as '''Bligh Island Reef''',<ref name="HTL">{{cite web| title = Bligh Reef| publisher = HomeTownLocator, Inc.| year = 2008| url = http://alaska.hometownlocator.com/maps/feature-map,ftc,1,fid,1420516,n,Bligh%20Reef.cfm| accessdate = 2008-05-17}}</ref> is a [[reef]] off the coast of [[Bligh Island]] in [[Prince William Sound]], [[Alaska]]. This was the location of the 1989 [[Exxon Valdez oil spill]].<ref name="faq">{{cite web| title = Frequently asked questions about the Spill|url=http://www.evostc.state.ak.us/History/FAQ.htm| work = History of the Spill| publisher = Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council |accessdate = 2008-03-10}}</ref> After the incident, US Code 33 § 2733 mandated the operation of an automated navigation light to prevent future collisions with the reef.<ref>[http://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/33/usc_sec_33_00002733----000-.html 33 USC 2733]</ref> Despite these efforts the tug Pathfinder ran aground on Bligh Reef on Dec 24, 2009, rupturing its tanks and spilling diesel fuel.<ref>{{cite news | title = Tug grounds on Bligh Reef | pages = 1| publisher = MarineLog| date = 2009-12-27| url = http://www.marinelog.com/DOCS/NEWSMMIX/2009dec00270.html| accessdate = 2010-01-20}}</ref> Bligh Reef is also where [[Alaska Steamship Company]]'s Olympia ran aground in 1910.<ref>{{cite news | title = Olympia's Passengers Safe| pages = 10| publisher = New York Times| date = 1910-12-13| url = http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A07EEDA1330E233A25750C1A9649D946196D6CF| accessdate = 2008-05-17}}</ref><ref>"Details of the Wreck of the S.S. Olympia", ''Fairbanks Daily News-Miner''. January 3, 1911. Page 2.</ref> Bligh Reef serves as a fishing ground for [[halibut]]<ref>{{cite web| title = Prince William Sound July Fishing Summary| publisher = Alaska Department of Fish & Game| year = 2008| url = http://www.sf.adfg.state.ak.us/region2/weekly/pwsjul.cfm| accessdate = 2008-05-17}}</ref> and a harvesting area for [[shrimp]].<ref>{{cite web| title = Prince William Sound Shrimp| work = Recreational Fishing Series| publisher = Alaska Department of Fish & Game| url = http://www.sf.adfg.state.ak.us/region2/pdfpubs/PWSshrimp.pdf| format = PDF| accessdate = 2008-05-17 }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The nearest town is [[Tatitlek, Alaska|Tatitlek]], which lies 7 miles to the northeast.<ref name="HTL"/> The reef was named after [[William Bligh]], of future ''[[HMS Bounty|Bounty]]'' fame, who served as [[Master Mariner|Master]] aboard ship during [[James Cook]]'s third world voyage. ==Notes== {{reflist}} {{coord|60|50|26|N|146|52|48|W|region:US-AK_scale:250000|display=title}} [[Category:Landforms of Alaska]] [[Category:Landforms of the United States]] [[Category:Landforms of Valdez–Cordova Census Area, Alaska]] [[Category:Exxon Valdez oil spill]] [[Category:Reefs of the Pacific Ocean]]
